segments.en: “Mendicants, a mendicant should live mindful and aware.
This is my instruction to you.
And how is a mendicant mindful?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

segments.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
segments.en: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sato hoti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.
And how is a mendicant aware?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno viditā vedanā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant knows feelings as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

segments.pli: Viditā vitakkā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.
segments.en: They know thoughts as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

segments.pli: Viditā saññā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.
segments.en: They know perceptions as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajāno hoti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant is aware.
A mendicant should live mindful and aware.
This is my instruction to you.”

suttaplex.blurb: Mindfulness is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. Situational awareness is watching the arising and passing of feelings, thoughts, and perceptions.
